title: Exhibition Moč in nemoč, Ljubljana
intro_text: As part of the general programme of the 2nd Festival of Tolerance in Ljubljana, Seiji Kimoto's Moč in nemoč (Power and Powerlessness) exhibition has been shown in Ljubljana Town Hall from February 25th to March 28th, 2016. The festival originated in Ljubljana from an initiative of concentration camp survivor and multiple Oscar winner Branko Lustig on the occasion of the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II in 2015. Its main intent is to promote tolerance as the basic building block of modern, civilized societies, and to raise awareness of a lack of tolerance towards marginalized groups in our time, on the basis of the experience of the Holocaust.
body_text: The festival is in the wider context of a regional initiative that began with the first Festival of Tolerance in Zagreb, Croatia, 10 years ago, and slowly evolved into a broad cultural project with cultural and educational activities in Croatia, Austria, Montenegro, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Slovenia. Its film presentations alone have been seen by over 100,000 visitors already. The 2nd Festival of Tolerance in Ljubljana was staged under the patronage of the President of the Republic of Slovenia, Borut Pahor, and was organized by Mini Teater Ljubljana and the Jewish Cultural Center Ljubljana in cooperation with JFF Zagreb.

body2_text: After the screenings of the festival, the festival exhibition Seiji Kimoto - Moč in nemoč was opened by Honorary Patron Mayor Zoran Janković and Robert Waltl, Director of Mini Teater and of the Jewish Cultural Center Ljubljana, on February 25th. Art historian Dr. Miklavž Komelj gave the eulogy. First shown here was the twin sculpture "Breakthrough", which was created by Kimoto for the victims of the concentration camp Loibl. The exhibition was supported by the European remembrance programme of the European Commission's EACEA.
body3_text: The vernissage was accompanied by a press conference on February 24th, and a video conference on February 26th with officials from Zagreb and Ljubljana about a (still) missing Holocaust memorial in both cities. The discussion concluded with the mutual wish to erect such a monument as a warning to future generations.
